explanations.summary: High shear rate reduces blood viscosity by TWO mechanisms: (1) Breaks up rouleaux (money-roll) RBC aggregates, (2) Deforms RBCs into elongated streamlined shapes. Blood is a non-Newtonian fluid - viscosity depends on shear rate.

whyCorrect.c: BOTH mechanisms contribute to shear-thinning of blood: (1) High shear disperses rouleaux formations that form at low shear; (2) High shear deforms flexible RBCs into streamlined shapes that slide past each other more easily.

whyIncorrect.a: Rouleaux dispersion is ONE mechanism, but not the only one.
whyIncorrect.b: RBC elongation/streamlining is ONE mechanism, but not the only one.
whyIncorrect.d: Wrong - blood viscosity IS shear-rate dependent. Blood is NON-Newtonian (viscosity changes with shear).

explanations.summary: Increased hematocrit: INCREASES viscosity → INCREASES peripheral resistance → DECREASES turbulence tendency (higher viscosity = lower Reynolds number). Does NOT affect Bohr effect (which is pH/CO2 dependent).

whyCorrect.a: Higher hematocrit increases viscosity. Higher viscosity DECREASES Reynolds number (Re = ρvD/η), making turbulent flow LESS likely.
whyCorrect.e: Higher hematocrit increases blood viscosity. By Poiseuille's law (R ∝ η), increased viscosity increases peripheral resistance.

whyIncorrect.b: Increased hematocrit INCREASES viscosity (more RBCs = thicker blood), not decreases.
whyIncorrect.c: Increased hematocrit INCREASES peripheral resistance (more viscous blood = higher resistance).
whyIncorrect.d: Bohr effect relates to pH/CO2 effects on hemoglobin O2 affinity - unrelated to hematocrit.

explanations.summary: Viscosity facts: (1) HEMATOCRIT (not proteins) is major determinant; (2) Fahraeus-Lindqvist = viscosity decreases in small vessels; (3) Viscosity DECREASES at high flow (shear-thinning); (4) High viscosity decreases turbulence; (5) Shear stress = viscosity × shear rate.

whyCorrect.b: Fahraeus-Lindqvist effect: Blood viscosity DECREASES in vessels <300μm diameter due to axial streaming of RBCs leaving plasma-rich layer at walls.
whyCorrect.d: High viscosity DECREASES turbulence tendency. Reynolds number = ρvD/η; higher η means lower Re, favoring laminar flow.
whyCorrect.e: Shear stress (τ) = viscosity (η) × shear rate (dv/dr). Higher viscosity means greater wall shear stress at same flow rate.

whyIncorrect.a: HEMATOCRIT is the major factor determining blood viscosity, not plasma proteins. RBCs contribute most to viscosity.
whyIncorrect.c: Viscosity DECREASES at high flow velocities (shear-thinning behavior) due to rouleaux breakup and RBC deformation.

explanations.summary: Fahraeus-Lindqvist effect: Blood viscosity DECREASES in narrow vessels (down to ~7-10μm). Cause: axial streaming concentrates RBCs in center, leaving cell-free plasma layer at wall. Below 7μm, viscosity increases again.

whyCorrect.e: Fahraeus-Lindqvist effect = viscosity DECREASES in narrow vessels (to ~7-10μm). RBCs stream axially, plasma layer at wall reduces apparent viscosity.

whyIncorrect.a: This describes shear-thinning, not Fahraeus-Lindqvist (which relates to vessel diameter, not flow velocity).
whyIncorrect.b: Opposite - viscosity DECREASES (not increases) in narrow vessels down to 7-10μm.
whyIncorrect.c: Wrong - viscosity IS affected by both flow velocity (shear-thinning) and vessel size (Fahraeus-Lindqvist).
whyIncorrect.d: Wrong - viscosity DECREASES with increased velocity (shear-thinning).

explanations.summary: Fahraeus-Lindqvist effect: Blood apparent viscosity DECREASES as vessel diameter narrows (to ~7-10μm) because RBCs concentrate in axial stream, leaving cell-poor plasma at vessel walls.

whyCorrect.c: Fahraeus-Lindqvist effect: Viscosity DECREASES in narrower vessels (down to 7-10μm diameter) due to axial streaming of RBCs and cell-free plasma layer at walls.

whyIncorrect.a: This describes the shear-thinning property (velocity-dependent), not Fahraeus-Lindqvist (diameter-dependent).
whyIncorrect.b: Opposite - viscosity DECREASES in narrow vessels. It only increases again below ~7μm (inverse F-L effect).
whyIncorrect.d: Wrong - blood viscosity varies with both shear rate and vessel size.
whyIncorrect.e: Opposite - viscosity DECREASES at high velocity (shear-thinning).

explanations.summary: RBC shape in circulation is determined primarily by PASSIVE DEFORMATION from shear forces. RBCs have no contractile proteins. Their membrane/cytoskeleton allows deformation but shear forces actually CAUSE the shape changes.

whyCorrect.d: RBC shape in flowing blood is determined by PASSIVE DEFORMATION due to shear forces. The biconcave disc becomes parachute-shaped in capillaries due to external forces, not internal activity.

whyIncorrect.a: Membrane elasticity ALLOWS deformation but doesn't DETERMINE shape - shear forces do.
whyIncorrect.b: Cytoskeleton (spectrin network) maintains RBC integrity and allows recovery, but shear forces determine shape.
whyIncorrect.c: RBCs have NO contractile proteins - they're anucleate cells with only cytoskeleton, no active shape changes.
